subject: RE: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
msgSnippet: I see your point about keeping JUnit lightweight and I agree that putting in assert counting may add more weight than it s worth.  It really depends on how
messageBody:
I see your point about keeping JUnit lightweight and I agree that putting in
assert counting may add more weight than it's worth. It really depends on
how many people want or use it.

I'm just trying to reduce some of our maintainence pain. :) Currently we
have to maintain changes to the Assert class, which sucks. I remember some
talk about changing the framework to allow for more "plugability". This
might be a good case for that.

As an aside, we count asserts instead of tests becase it's a finer grained
metric. Right now we only have 8 functional test methods, but 170
assertions. When we add to a functional test we don't create a new test
method, we add some more assertions to an already existing test. It would
be harder to see progress if we tracked test cases.

Subject: Re: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?


I've been working with JUnit for about a year now and I never had the
desire to count "asserts". That might be the reason it's not in the
framework. I, for one, hope it does not become part of the framework.
Moreover, I have grave concerns that once JUnit goes truly Open Source, it
will cease to be a lightweight, simple test framework.

Thoughts?

it isn't part of the framework? Since a few of us have already done it,
I'm
sure we could make the change pretty easily.

Matt

From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: Monday, July 16, 2001 10:40 AM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown
exception ?


We have modified JUnit to count asserts, because we find that to be
interesting data for metrics. Therefore, since we are implying that
something went wrong when it was supposed to, we do an assert to add to the
count.
